div.head: Sand @ for lead
div.ab: Recipe: Grey soot from the furnace of the silversmiths, quick lime, and ana flour, moistened according to the art, being the finest possible.
left-top The grey soot of locksmiths, which is held in the forge, is very fine once ground, molds very neatly, & releases very well.

div.head: Sand for copper medals
div.ab: Recipe: Hat felt burnt over a covered fire, dross of iron, & burnt bone, all of which ground very finely & crushed & watered with saltwater; & make a paste of it & mold it, & wipe it over a straw fire. @These three sands, pulverized and very finely ground on porphyry, mold well, and I think that separately each of them is very good. Burnt hat felt molds very neatly and releases very neatly.
left-top Plaster molds very neatly but it becomes porous. Bone has scarcely any body unless it has iron dross. Felt makes it release.

div.head: Another sand
div.ab: Charcoal of vine shoots & clay earth, bien recuitte & well sieved, as much of one as the other, & joine them together with well-beaten eggs’ glair, then calcine in the furnace, & to use it, moisten it with vinegar.

div.head: Another for lead
div.ab: Recipe: Finely crushed slate, & calcinée pumice stone mixed together. Calcine them in a well covered pot, & thrice stoppered over a good fire, & each time moisten them with vernis.

div.head: Another
div.ab: Recipe: p A tile little baked, ground & moistened in white wine with burnt black trasse paper. And if you add burnt horse dung, it will be all the better. Moisten with egg glair.
left-bottom Trasse paper burnt over a closed fire is reduced just as charcoal & very soft black, molds neatly & makes it release well mixed with the others.

div.head: Excellent sand
div.ab: Alabaster, calcined in a crucible over charcoal fire so that when touching it, it turns into powder. Once cold, pulverise it finely, pass it through a double sieve, & and render it as if impalpable. And d with one lb of alabaster, one needs one ms>℥ of sal ammoniac. Mix well & incorporate everything together, then put them in a cellar or a damp place. And with this paste, mold what you will need, & next dry the mold in the fire, & cast whatever you wish, while the sand is hot. And you will cast as neaty as the main one, & the sand can still be used by placing it in a damp place & drying it in the fire.
